For each of the statements below indicate if it is true or false.
For a function f\from \RNr[3]\to \RNr[2] , ‘ \Vect{a} is in f^{-1}(2,0) ’ means that f(\Vect{a})=(2,0) .
True!
The set f^{-1}(2,0) consists of all those \Vect{x} in \RNr[3] with f(\Vect{x}) = (2,0) . According to this definition the statement in question is true.
For a function f\from \RNr[3]\to \RNr[2] , ‘ \Vect{a} is in f^{-1}(2,0) ’ means that f(\mathbf{a})=\mathbf{a} .
False!
The set f^{-1}(2,0) consists of all those \Vect{x} in \RNr[3] with f(\Vect{x}) = (2,0) . According to this definition the statement in question is false.
For a function f\from \RNr[3]\to \RNr[2] , if ‘ \Vect{a} is in f^{-1}(2,0) ’ then \Vect{a} is in \RNr[3] .
True!
The set f^{-1}(2,0) consists of all those \Vect{x} in \RNr[3] with f(\Vect{x}) = (2,0) . Thus, if \Vect{a} is in f^{-1}(2,0) , then \Vect{a} must be a vector in \RNr[3] .
For a function f\from \RNr[3]\to \RNr[2] , if ‘ \Vect{a} is in f^{-1}(2,0) ’ then \Vect{a} is in \RNr[2] .
False!
The set f^{-1}(2,0) consists of all those \Vect{x} in \RNr[3] with f(\Vect{x}) = (2,0) . Thus, if \Vect{a} is in f^{-1}(2,0) , then \Vect{a} must be a vector in \RNr[3] , not in \RNr[2] .
